Authors:
Anne M Estes, David J. Hearn, Emilie C. Snell-Rood, Michele
Feindler, Karla Feeser, Tselotie Abebe, Julie C. Dunning Hotopp, Armin
P. Moczek
Title:
Vertical transmission of a unique gut microbiome in the dung
beetle, Onthophagus taurus (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae)
Keywords:
symbiosis, vertical transmission, microbiome,
holometabolous development, dung beetle, nutrient limited
Abstract:
Insects feeding on plant sap, blood, and other
nutritionally incomplete diets are associated with mutualistic bacteria
that supplement missing nutrients. The dung of herbivorous mammals
contains more than 86% cellulose and lacks amino acids essential for
insect development and reproduction. Yet one of the most ecologically
necessary and evolutionarily successful groups of beetles, the dung
beetles (Scarabaeinae) feeds primarily, or exclusively, on dung. This
suggests that dung beetles rely on mutualistic bacteria to provide
nutrients missing from dung. The nesting behaviors of the female parent
and the feeding behaviors of the larvae suggest that a microbiome is
vertically transmitted through the brood ball. We establish the vertical
transmission of the microbiome in the bull-headed dung beetle,
Onthophagus taurus, using sterile technique and a combination of
molecular and culture-based techniques. Beetles were reared on
autoclaved dung and the microbiome was characterized for all lifestages.
An ~1425 bp region of the 16S rRNA identified Pseudomonadaceae,
Enterobacteriaceae, and Comamonadaceae as the most common microbiome
families across all life stages and populations. Phylotyping analyses
based on lepA and gyrB amplicons of cultured isolates placed the
isolates closest to Enterobacter cloacae, Providencia stuartii,
Pusillimonas sp., Pedobacter heparinus, and Lysinibacillus sphaericus.
The cultured isolates from the 3rd instar digestive system overlapped
significantly with the uncultured community suggesting a largely
culturable, vertically inherited digestive system microbiome.
Microscopic analysis of brood balls constructed from sterile dung
reveals secretions and microbes only in the chamber the female prepares
for the egg. Given the use of autoclaved dung and sterile techniques,
the parental female is the only source of the microbiome for the
offspring indicating that the O. taurus females transmit a specific
microbiome to their offspring through the brood chamber. The tical
transmission of the dung beetle microbiome highlights 45 the maintenance
and likely importance of this newly-characterized bacterial
community.
